newsitem.title: CHINA: HK&Shanghai Hotels down on dull earnings.
newsitem.headline: HK&Shanghai Hotels down on dull earnings.

text.p: Shares of Hong Kong & Shanghai Hotels Ltd fell after the company reported unexciting interim earnings growth, brokers said on Thursday.
"The earnings growth did not seem to be very exciting when the dividend payout was the same with last year, and that triggered selling," said Michael Ng, dealing director at Sassoon Securities.
"They are not great results," said one trader at a European brokerage firm. "If they do take in the handover period, you would have anticipated slightly stronger growth."
Shares of the hotel group were down HK$0.25 or 2.15 percent at HK$11.40 in late trade after touching an intraday low of HK$11.30 in the afternoon. Volume was 2.35 million shares.
The hotelier posted an eight percent rise in interim profit to HK$412 million for the six months to June 30 and declared an interim dividend of HK$0.15, unchanged with the same period last year.

Hongkong and Shanghai Hotels executives said the company may see a slowdown in earnings growth in second half 1997 due to weak demand in the remaining summer months and renovation work at the Kowloon Hotel.
